raw_text:
Duran Duran show set for US TV
 
 Chart stars Duran Duran are to appear in a VH1 special in the US including interviews and concert footage.
 
 The show airs on Tuesday and will feature a studio performance, behind the scenes footage and fan interviews. "They seemed like a perfect fit with our audience," said Rick Krim, VH1's vice president of music and talent. The band recently released a new album, Astronaut, the first from the original line-up since 1983. They will also tour Japan and the US next year.
 
 "When we started playing together, we didn't try and make a really sort of mature album. We just really wanted to make a great Duran Duran album," said keyboard player Nick Rhodes. "It's pretty much in line with a lot of stuff out there." Duran Duran are currently promoting the album's second single, What Happens Tomorrow.
 
 Simon Le Bon said earlier this year that the group were not trying to update their sound too much. "We wouldn't want to lose them [older fans] by trying too hard by trying to connect with a new audience," the singer said. Le Bon also said the five members were getting on very well. "We're like any people who get very close. Sometimes you argue with each other. But the fact is we inspire each other musically. "Nobody else does it for me," he said. "It's just very special."
llama3.2:1b:
Duran Duran will appear in a VH1 special in the US, featuring interviews and concert footage, along with a studio performance and behind-the-scenes content.

The band recently released Astronaut, their first new album since 1983, which they described as being "pretty much in line" with other recent music.

Simon Le Bon stated that the group's sound is not intended to change significantly, even for older fans, and that they value staying true to themselves musically.

Keyboard player Nick Rhodes noted they made an album aimed at making a great Duran Duran album, not updating sound too much to keep older fans engaged. Simon Le Bon mentioned that the band members are doing well together, inspired each other musically.

smollm:1.7b:

The show airs on VH1 and will feature a studio performance, behind-the-scenes footage and fan interviews. The band released their new album Astronaut last year, touring Japan and the US next year. They will also tour Japan this year.

Duran Duran are currently promoting their second single What Happens Tomorrow, which was released in 2019. The group is not trying to update their sound too much, but rather focus on making a great new album. Simon Le Bon said earlier this year that the band were not trying to connect with a new audience by trying too hard to update their sound.

The five members of Duran Duran are getting on very well, and they inspire each other musically. Nobody else does it for me, it's just very special.

<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Duran Duran appearing on a TV show in the US. Let me read through it carefully.

The first sentence talks about a special show set for the US TV channel, called Duran Duran Show Set for US. The chart stars Duran Duran are going to appear in this special, including interviews and concert footage. That's pretty clear—so I should note that the show is on HD in the US.

Next, it mentions that the show airs on Tuesday. So I need to include the airing date as Tuesday, 2023, but maybe not specific details beyond that. The show will feature a studio performance, behind-the-scenes footage, and fan interviews. That's helpful information for someone interested in looking forward to the show.

Rick Krim, the vice president of music and talent at VH1, says they're a perfect fit with the audience. It mentions the band has just released their new album, Astronaut, which is the first since 1983. They'll also tour Japan and the US next year. That adds context about the potential release and future tours.

Then there's some background on the group members. Nick Rhodes mentioned that they didn't try to make a mature album; it was a great album. He said their style is similar to others out there, maybe because of their connection to fans. I should highlight that their music hasn't changed much and remains close-knit.

Simon Le Bon discussed not updating the sound too much for the new audience. He stressed that they're getting very close among themselves and inspire each other musically. Some might argue but they all help each other, especially listeners who are old friends. That's good for fans looking to stay connected.

I also need to include their promotional efforts. They're promoting the album's second single, What Happens Tomorrow. So that's a key point about their current work and potential future projects.

Putting it all together, I should structure the summary to highlight the show details, airing date, content features, group fit, new album release, tour plans, members' music style, Le Bon's approach, and their promotional efforts. That covers all the important points without adding extra details beyond what was provided.
</think>

The Duran Duran Show Set for US is set to air on HD TV in the United States, featuring interviews and concert footage. The show will also include a studio performance, behind-the-scenes footage, and fan interviews. The group's vice president of music and talent, Rick Krim, notes they fit well with the audience, supported by a new album, Astronaut, which is their first since 1983, and future tours in Japan and the U.S. Nick Rhodes mentioned their style remains similar to others out there, emphasizing connection over attempts at maturity. Simon Le Bon highlighted that he didn't update the sound too much for the new audience, stating they're getting very close and inspiring each other musically, especially among older fans. The group is also promoting their album's second single, What Happens Tomorrow.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Duran Duran, a renowned British band, will perform in a VH1 special on US television. The show, airing on Tuesday, includes interviews, concert footage, and a studio performance of their recent single "What Happens Tomorrow" from the album Astronaut, their first with the original line-up since 1983. VH1's Rick Krim praised Duran Duran as a fitting match for their audience. The band is also set to tour Japan and the US next year. Keyboardist Nick Rhodes noted that they aimed to create a strong, mature album without overhauling their classic sound to appeal to both older fans and new listeners. Lead singer Simon Le Bon emphasized the group's camaraderie, stating that they inspire each other musically despite occasional disagreements. He expressed deep appreciation for his bandmates, declaring their bond as unique and special.
reference: We just really wanted to make a great Duran Duran album," said keyboard player Nick Rhodes.Chart stars Duran Duran are to appear in a VH1 special in the US including interviews and concert footage.Simon Le Bon said earlier this year that the group were not trying to update their sound too much.Le Bon also said the five members were getting on very well."We wouldn't want to lose them [older fans] by trying too hard by trying to connect with a new audience," the singer said."They seemed like a perfect fit with our audience," said Rick Krim, VH1's vice president of music and talent."Nobody else does it for me," he said.
